description: The origin of the verb is unknown; it is perhaps related to Old French troncer, troncher, troncir, tronchir (“to cut; to cut a piece from; to retrench”), from Old French tronce, tronche (“stump; piece of wood”). However, the English and Old French words differ in meaning.
The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: An act of trouncing: a severe beating, a thrashing; a thorough defeat.

verbs.description: trounce (third-person singular simple present trounces, present participle trouncing, simple past and past participle trounced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To beat or overcome thoroughly, to defeat heavily; especially (games, sports) to win against (someone) by a wide margin.
examples: The Mexican team trounced the Americans by 10 goals to 1.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To chastise or punish physically or verbally; to scold with abusive language.
(transitive, Britain, regional) To punish by bringing a lawsuit against; to sue.

description: The verb is derived from Middle English traunce, trauncen, trancen (“to move about (?); to prance (?); to trample the ground”) (whence modern English trance with the same senses), possibly either:
The noun is probably derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: A walk involving some difficulty or effort; a trek, a tramp, a trudge.
A journey involving quick travel; also, one that is dangerous or laborious.

verbs.description: trounce (third-person singular simple present trounces, present participle trouncing, simple past and past participle trounced) (Britain, dialectal)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To walk heavily or with some difficulty; to tramp, to trudge.
(intransitive) To pass across or over; to traverse.
(intransitive) To travel quickly over a long distance.
